East China Normal University Shanghai 200062 China Graphical abstract The mono-metal relay catalysis is a good strategy for one-pot multi-step cascade process in which the specific catalysis can be switched upon the ligand exchange to match the requirements for each independent reaction but without mutual interference and quenching problem. Herein, the one-pot cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of terminal alkynes was achieved by taking advantages of the mono-metallic (Pd) relay catalysis, wherein the two kinds of divergent di-phosphines of L1 and DTBPMB were involved. In this Pd(OAc)2-L1-DTBPMB system, due to the steric bulkiness of L1 and DTBPMB, the two type of catalysts including Pd(OAc)2-L1 and Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB co-existed independently and compatibly. Pd(OAc)2-L1 system was only in charge of the first-step carbonylation of alkynes towards the branched α,β-unsaturated esters with gem-positioned double bond. Subsequent, Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB system took over the carbonylation of the branched α,β-unsaturated esters to afford the target diesters. It was indicated Pd(OAc)2 -L1 system was an efficient and stable catalyst which could be recycled upon 15 runs for the first-step carbonylation. Anyway, Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB system easily underwent deactivation, which degraded the recyclability of the Pd(OAc)2-L1-DTBPMB coupling system for this cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation. Keywords Relay catalysis Bis-alkoxycarbonylation Cascade reaction Palladium catalyst Di-phosphines Data availability I have shared the link to my data at the Attach File step. 1 Introduction 2-Substituted succinate diesters are particularly important structural units, with widespread applications in the materials [1] and pharmaceutical fields [2] for the synthesis of polyamides [3], matrix metalloproteinase inhibitors [4], and other high-value chemicals [4–8]. To date, due to the difficulty in preparing (2-susbtituted) succinic acids, only a handful of protocols have been provided for the synthesis of succinate diesters (and the derivatives), including oxidative bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkenes and bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes with Pd-catalysts (Scheme 1 -A). In considerations of low cost of raw materials, high atom economy and avoided explosion risk as the required advances in green chemistry, the cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes is more preferred to the oxidative bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkenes. The latter suffers from the low selectivity, many side reactions, and the use of risky oxidants (such as benzoquinone, air and O2) in stoichiometric amount [9–13]. In recent decade, the cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes have attracted more attentions as a promising and green alterative for synthesis of succinate diesters (derivatives) [14–18]. In 2018, Pd-catalyzed cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes for the preparation of diesters was reported by Beller's group [19] and our group [20], which clearly disclosed that there were two catalytic cycles involved in this cascade reaction. It means that the conversion of alkynes to α,β-unsaturated esters is followed by the continuous conversion of α,β-unsaturated esters to diesters under the same catalytic conditions. Therefore, the fulfillment of this cascade bis-carbonylation sequence is under the condition that the involved catalytic system should exhibit good performance for both the two reactions. However, the starting materials for each reaction are totally different in this cascade process. Alkynes are the reactants for the first-step alkoxycarbonylation whereas α,β-unsaturated esters (as the functionalized alkenes) are the reactants for the second-step alkoxycarbonylation. In comparison, the reactivity of CC double bond in α,β-unsaturated esters is less labile than that of CC triple bond in alkynes. Hence, the identical activity of the sole catalyst usually doesn’t match the requirements for the effective activation of the differentiated unsaturated bonds (COCC/CC bond). In general, the harsh conditions have to be applied in order to spur the second-step of carbonylation of the unreactive α,β-unsaturated esters, which undoubtedly are beyond the requirement for the first-step reaction, leading to the prevailing side-reactions like polymerizations of alkynes/α,β-unsaturated esters [19–21]. The mono-metal relay catalysis is a preferred strategy for one-pot multi-step cascade process in which the required catalytic performance can be switched timely upon the ligand exchange to match the requirements for each reaction independently without mutual interference and quenching problem as illustrated in Scheme 1-B [22–25]. In 2022, Dong's group successfully applied this strategy to asymmetric double hydroxycarbonylation [26], wherein the two different phosphine ligands in combination with the same Pd-precursor was presented to construct two types of Pd-catalytic systems, and each was responsible for only one step of the double hydroxycarbonylation of alkynes. Evidently, such relay catalysis strategy can provide a promising protocol for one-pot cascade process via developing two independent and compatible catalysts upon ligand-exchange. In principle, the bulky steric hindrance of the involved two types of ligands is basically required to guarantee that only one type of ligand can be accommodated to occupy one Pd-center without crossing-coordination by another. Highlighted by the strategy of mono-metal relay catalysis taking advantage of ligand-exchange of the two types of ligands with bully steric hindrance, we try to apply this principle to the cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes for the synthesis of important chemicals of 2-substituted succinate diesters. It has been disclosed in the literatures [27–30] that, the basic pyridyl-scaffolded phosphines not only can coordinate to a mental center to accelerate the reaction rate but also can act as a proton-shuttle to exert stereo-directing influence in favor of the branched α,β-unsaturated esters in mono-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes. For example, the Drent’s ligand of 2-pyridyldiphenylphosphine (2-PyPPh2) has been proved one of the most effective P,N hybrid ligands in Pd-catalyzed Markovnikov’s alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes with the practical application for production of methyl methacrylate (MMA) from propyne [27,28], but without the ability to continue to carbonylate the second double-bond positioned in the as-formed α,β-unsaturated esters. In contrast, the commercial diphosphine of DTBPMB [1,2-bis((di-tert-butylphosphino)methyl)benzene] has been reported pioneeringly by Beller as a sterically bulky ligand to direct the carbonylated products in favor of the linear regioselectivity in Pd-catalyzed bis-alkoxycarbonylation of 1,3-dienes [31], which implies that DTBPMB-based Pd-catalyst is inherently endowed with the ability to catalyze the functionalized alkenes of α,β-unsaturated esters to afford the dicarbonylated compounds. On the other hand, It has been noted in our previous work [20,21] that, as for the cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes, only the branched α,β-unsaturated ester rather than the linear one formed in the first-step carbonylation can be successfully transformed into the target diesters over the suitable catalytic systems. Herein, with the mono-metallic relay catalysis strategy in mind, and highlighted by the advantage of the Drent’s P,N-hybrid ligand of 2-PyPPh2 in high stereo-direction to the branched α,β-unsaturated esters in mono-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes as well as the ability of DTBPMB for carbonylation of the functionalized alkenes (like α,β-unsaturated esters), the pyrazinyl-scaffolded diphosphine of L1 featured with double steric hindrance of 2-PyPPh2 were synthesized on purpose, which was in combination with the typical bulky diphosphine of DTBPMB to fulfill the relay catalysis over Pd-catalyst for cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes for the first time. For comparison, the diphosphines of L2-L4 as the analogues of L1 were synthesized and investigated in parallel. 2 Results and discussion In order to fulfil the mono-metallic relay catalysis, the two types of phosphines of LA and LB were selected on purpose. LA -series included the as-synthesized diphosphines of L1-L4 featured with rigid and bulky steric configuration along with Drent’s ligand of 2-PyPPh2 as a comparison. As indicated in Fig. 1 , compared to 2-PyPPh2 (δ −3.99), each of the diphosphines (L1-L4) also corresponds to one P-signal at due to the highly symmetrical structure. As for pyrazinyl-based di-phosphines of L1 and L2, the P-signals shift to the much higher-field due to the electron-rich property of pyrazinyl group in comparison to pyridyl-one scaffolded in L3 and 2-PyPPh2. The crystal structure of L1 (Fig. 2 ) demonstrates that L1 is featured with a rigid steric configuration with P⋅⋅⋅P distance of 6.3609(9) Å, which is impossible to develop a bidental chelation to Pd-center. The TG/DTG analyses (see Fig. S2 in SI) showed that L1-L4 had good thermal stability, which did not undergo decomposition until 300 °C in air flow. LB -series included the commercial di-phosphines of DTBPMB, Xantphos and BINAP also characteristic with the bulky steric hindrance. In this way, the co-existence of LA and LB with the same Pd-precursor can provide two independent and compatible catalytic systems of Pd-LA and Pd-LB without the possibility to afford LA-Pd-LB system. The bis-alkoxycarbonylation of phenylacetylene (1a) with MeOH was investigated as a model reaction in the presence of the same Pd-precursor and these two types of the ligands. The optimization of reaction conditions in terms of Pd-precursors and acid-additives were provided in Tables S1 and S2 of SI. As shown in Table 1 , under the optimal conditions [Pd(OAc)2 1 mol%, PTSA·H2O 10 mol%, CO 3 MPa, 100 °C], within 0.5 h, with Pd(OAc)2-L1 catalytic system in absence of LB , phenylacetylene (1a) rapidly converted to 2a with 100 % conversion and 100 % regio-selectivity in the first-step reaction without second-step carbonylation ensuing, affording 2a (methyl 2-phenylacrylate) in CG-yield of 97 % (Entry 1). When the reaction time was prolonged from 0.5 h to 20 h, the formation of 3a was not observed but resulting in the dramatically decreased yield of 2a down to 42 %, due to the serious self-polymerization of 2a (Entry 2). Interestingly, even at RT, 100 % conversion of 1a towards 2a (96 % GC-yield) was obtained in 4 h (Entry 3). These results indicated that Pd(OAc)2 -L1 system only exhibited excellent activity for the first-step Markovnikov’s carbonylation of phenylacetylene towards the branched α,β-unsaturated ester of 2a but lacked of the ability to further catalyze 2a towards 3a, which was in consistence to the behavior of Drent’s ligand of 2-PyPPh2 (Entry 1 vs 8) [27]. The applied much harsher conditions (Entry 2, 20 h; Entry 3, 120 °C) just led to the serious polymerization of 1a and/or 2a but did not benefit the second-step carbonylation. In comparison, when L2-L4 were used instead of L1 to regulate the steric hindrance and chelation mode, no reaction occurred at RT under the same conditions (Entries 5–7). Only when the temperature increased from RT up to 100 °C, the conversions of 1a to 2a happened but with much lower efficiency (Entries 9–11), indicating the much lower activities of L2-L4 based-Pd catalysts than that of Pd(OAc)2-L1 system. When the commercial di-phosphines of DTBPMB, Xantphos and BINAP among LB -series was applied respectively in absence of L1, at 100 °C within 0.5 h, the linear intermediate product of 2b was formed universally and the diester of 3a was nearly unobserved (Entries 12–14). Notably, with DTBPMB, the selectivity of 2b was as high as 95 % but the transformation rate was quite slow, only giving 22 % conversion of 1a (Entry 12). While the reaction time was prolonged from 0.5 h to 20 h, the continuous carbonylation of 2a towards 3a ensued smoothly but the carbonylation of 2b to 3a failed (Entries 15–17), implying that the linear α,β-unsaturated ester of 2b with the embedded double bond could not carry on the second-step carbonylation as observed in our previous report [20]. As a result, the formation of 3a over DTMPMB with preference to linear 2b was poor, only in 2 % yield (Entry 15). These outcomes indicated that the individual use of DTBPMB, Xantphos or BINAP with regioselectivity-preference to the linear 2b was not qualified for this cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes either. The above results (Entries 1–17) demonstrated that any individual no matter coming from LA -series (L1-L4) or LB -series (DTBPMB, Xantphos, and BINAP) neither could confer to Pd(OAc)2 the required catalytic performance for this cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation. Encouragingly, as indicated in Entry 18 of Table 1, the combination of L1 with DTBPMB corresponded to the formation of 3a in the yield of 90 % (Entry 18), implying that, with Pd(OAc)2 -L1 system, 1a was rapidly carbonylated into the branched 2a without the interference from Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB since the reaction rate of the first-step carbonylation from 1a to 2a was much faster with Pd(OAc)2 -L1 system than that with Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB one as indicated in Entry 1 vs Entry 12. And then the subsequent transformation of 2a towards 3a had to be taken over by Pd(OAc)2 -DTBPMB since Pd(OAc)2 -L1 was lacking of the ability to catalyze the second-step carbonylation as indicated in Entries 1–4. In contrast, the combination of L1 with Xantphos corresponded to the formation of 3a in the lower yield of 47 % along with the co-existence of the unreacted 2a and 2b (Entry 19), due to the competition of Pd(OAc)2-Xantphos system against L1-Pd(OAc)2 in the first-step carbonylation with propensity to form the linear 2b (Entries 13 vs 1). The combination of L1 with BINAP also delivered the similar outcome as that of L1 with Xantphos, only giving 3a in the yield of 39 % (Entry 20). Consistently, as 2b was once formed over Pd(OAc)2 -Xantphos [or Pd(OAc)2 -BINAP] system with the competitive activity against Pd(OAc)2 -L1 (Entry 13 or 14 vs 1), its continuous carbonylation was too hard to ensue under the applied conditions. As for the combination of 2-PyPPh2 with DTBPMB in comparison to L1-DTBPMB combination, the lower yield of 3a of 78 % was obtained also due to the formation of the linear and unconvertable 2b (Entries 21 vs 18), revealing the inherent interference of DTBPMB against 2-PyPPh2 in the first-step carbonylation because of the less steric bulkiness of 2-PyPPh2 in comparison to L1. It was noted that the molar ratio of Pd/L1/DTBPMB could also affect this cascade bis-carbonylation. An increase amount of DTBPMB in this composite catalytic system with Pd/L1/DTBPMB of 1/2/2 led to a decreased yield of 3a down to 22 % (Entry 22), due to the prevailing formation of the linear 2b in the first-step carbonylation, which implied that the presence of large amount of DTBPMB would unavoidably interfere and counteract the activity of L1-based Pd-catalyst. And a decreased amount of DTBPMB with Pd/L1/DTBPMB of 1/2/0.5 could dramatically decelerate the reaction rate of the second-step carbonylation, also corresponding to the decreased yield of 3a (28 %, Entry 23). Hence, the Pd/L1/DTBPMB molar ratio of 1/2/1 was the best choice. Accordingly, the combination of L1 with DTBPMB could warrant Pd(OAc)2 (Pd/L1/DTBPMB = 1/2/1) to fulfill a successful relay catalysis for the cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of phenylacetylene (1a) to produce the dimethyl 2-phenylsuccinate of 3a, wherein the co-existence of L1 and DTBPMB with Pd(OAc)2 could divergently result in the two independent catalytic systems including the L1-based Pd-catalyst and the DTBPMB-based Pd-one due to the mutual repulsion of the selected two ligands both with the steric bulkiness. Then the L1-based Pd-system was only highly active for the first-step carbonylation of 1a towards the branched 2a, and the DTBPMB-based Pd-system was selectively responsible for the second-step carbonylation of 2a towards 3a. The activity of Pd(OAc)2-L1 system for the second-step carbonylation was void. And the activity of Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB system for the first-step carbonylation was overwhelmingly surpassed by Pd(OAc)2-L1 system and then completely suppressed. The kinetic evolving processes for the cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of phenylacetylene (1a) further convinced such successful relay catalysis with Pd(OAc)2-L1-DTBPMB catalytic system as depicted in Fig. 3 . Clearly, in the initial 0.5 h, the first-step carbonylation of 1a was fully accomplished, giving the branched 2a as the absolutely major product (2a/2b = 96/4). Later on, 2a was gradually converted to 3a until it was totally consumed in 20 h. Nevertheless, the minorly formed linear 2b was hardly depleted. Evidently, the reaction rate of the second-step carbonylation of 2a towards 3a driven by Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB catalyst was much slower than that of the first-step carbonylation of 1a to 2a with Pd(OAc)2-L1 catalyst. And the second-step carbonylation was the rate-controlling step for the overall cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation. The control experiments for the separate reactions were also conducted to elucidate the independent and compatible behaviors of L1 and DTBPMB in this cascade bis-alkoxycarbonykation (Scheme 2 ). With the Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB catalytic system, the branched 2a could convert to 3a smoothly in the yield of 94 % within 20 h (eq. 1), whereas the conversion of the linear 2b to 3a totally failed (eq. 2). These results convinced that in the first-step carbonylation, the regioselectivity to the branched 2a was absolutely required in order to guarantee the smoothy second-step carbonylation. In contrast, under the same reaction conditions with the L1-Pd(OAc)2 catalytic system, neither 2a nor 2b could be carbonylated to afford 3a (eqs. 3 and 4), which indicated that Pd(OAc)2-L1 system was absolutely inactive for the carbonylation of the inert α,β-unsaturated esters (2a and 2b). As shown in eq. 6 vs eq. 5, the presence of L1 didn’t influence the performance of Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB system at all, further validating the feasibility of the mono-metallic relay catalysis by taking advantage of the two divergent ligands of L1 and DTBPMB. The 31P NMR spectroscopy Fig. 4 -(5) further confirmed that, upon mixing L1 and DTBPMB (double ligands) in Pd(OAc)2 and PTSA⋅H2O, the resultant L1-based Pd-complex (ca. 21 ∼ 24 and −2 ∼ −6 ppm) and DTBPMB-based Pd-complex (ca. 70 ppm) maintained as intact as the fresh single-ligand based Pd-complex [Fig. 4-(5) vs (2) and (4)], which shed light on the fact that L1 and DTBPMB indeed could individually coordinated to Pd-center to afford two kinds independent and compatible Pd-catalyst without any interference. Next, the recycling uses with Pd(OAc)2 -L1 and Pd(OAc)2 -L1-DTBPMB were carried out respectively as shown in Fig. 5 . In the recycling experiments, only the feedstock of 1a was added in each run while the products were accumulated in the autoclave without isolation. It was indicated that the activity and stability of Pd(OAc)2-L1 system were good enough that it could be reused for 15 cycles without the activity loss. Since Pd(OAc)2 -L1 system was only highly active for the mono-carbonylation of phenylacetylene (1a) towards 2a with 100 % selectivity, no formation of 3a was observed at all in the course of long-time recycling uses. Upon 15-run consecutive runs, 100 %% conversion of 1a as well as the 100 % regio-selectivity of 2a always maintained in each run. The decreased yields of 2a from 97 % down to 85 % as observed was ascribed to the propensity to the polymerization of 1a/2a while the catalyst concentration was diluted by the cumulative 2a. However, when Pd(OAc)2-L1-DTBPMB system was applied to the recycling experiments at 100 °C, the catalyst deactivated rapidly upon 3-runs along with the serious Pd-black precipitation, which implied that the catalyst of Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB in charge of the second step carbonylation of 2a towards 3a was more easily subjected to deactivation than Pd(OAc)2 -L1 system in charge of the first-step carbonylation. The in situ high-pressure FT-IR spectral analysis over Pd(OAc)2-L1 and Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB for the separate carbonylation (see Fig. S1 in SI) suggested that, the first-step carbonylation (to convert 1a to 2a) catalyzed by Pd(OAc)2-L1 system might not follow Pd-H mechanism since no Pd-H active species was observed but the product of 2a (ν 1710 cm−1) was generated efficiently. In comparison, the second-step carbonylation (to convert 2a to 3a) catalyzed by Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB did follow the Pd-H mechanism with the observation of Pd-H active species at 1948 cm−1 [20], whose formation co-related with the concurrent generation of 3a. Therein, during the formation of Pd-H species upon oxidation of Pd(0) by proton (Pd0 + H+ → PdII-H), Pd0-atom aggregation and then Pd-black precipitation was prone to happen, accounting for the poor stability of Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB as indicated in Fig. 5. It is believed that PTSA⋅H2O may serve as a proton-donor and then initiate the addition of proton to the alkyne in the first-step carbonylation without the need to form Pd-H species. In the second-step carbonylation, PTSA⋅H2O as a proton-donor participates the formation of Pd-H active species upon oxidation of Pd(0) by H+. With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, the substrate scope was explored over Pd(OAc)2-L1-DTBPMB relay catalysts. As shown in Table 2 , a variety of terminal alkynes could smoothly convert to the corresponding diesters in the moderate to good yields (isolated yields: 42–88 %). As for phenylacetylene derivatives, there was no obvious discrimination on the steric and electronic effects for the substituent (like Me-, MeO-, F-, or Cl-) on phenyl ring, and the yield of diesters (3b-3g) was obtained in the yield of 62–76 %. When the alcohols like EtOH, iPrOH, and nPrOH were used respectively instead of MeOH, the corresponding diesters (3h-3j) were obtained in the yield of 64–76 %. It was noted that when the terminal alkyl alkynes like 1-hexyne and 1-octyne were applied, the relatively lower yields of 42 % and 47 % were obtained for the corresponding diesters (3k and 3l), due to the prevailing isomerization of the terminal alkyl alkynes towards the internal alkyl alkynes, which unavoidably resulted in the formation of the α,β-unsaturated esters without gem-positioned double bond in the first-step carbonylation. 3 Conclusions The cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of terminal alkynes was accomplished by taking advantages of the mono-metallic (Pd) relay catalysis to afford the target diesters in the isolated yields of 42–88 % under mild conditions (Pd 1 mol%, 100 oC, 20 h, PCO 3 MPa), wherein the two kinds of divergent di-phosphines of L1 and DTBPMB with steric bulkiness were applied. It was found that L1-based Pd-catalyst and DTBPMB-based Pd-catalyst co-existed independently and compatibly without mutual interference. Then, in this one-pot cascade reaction, L1-based Pd-catalyst was responsible for the first-step carbonylation to produce the branched α,β-unsaturated esters with gem-positioned double bond whereas DTBPMB-based Pd-catalyst for the second-set carbonylation to convert the branched α,β-unsaturated esters to 2-substituted succinate diesters in the isolated yields of 42–88 %. It was found that L1-based Pd-catalyst was an efficient and stable catalyst which could be recycled upon 15 runs for the first-step carbonylation. However, DTBPMB-based Pd-catalyst easily underwent deactivation, which degraded the recyclability of the Pd(OAc)2-L1-DTBPMB coupling system for this cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation. However, this Pd(OAc)2-L1-DTBPMB coupling system was only effective to the substrates of terminal alkynes with preference to produce the gem-positioned branched α,β-unsaturated esters. 4 Experimental section 4.1 Reagents and analysis The chemical reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Solvents were dried and distilled before use. The 1H/13C/19F NMR and 31P NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 500 spectrometer under ambient temperature conditions. Gas chromatography (GC) was performed on an Agilent 6890 equipped with a DB-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). GC-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) which equipped with a DB-Wax capillary column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) was recorded on an Agilent 6890 instrument equipped with an Agilent 5973 mass selective detector. The TG/DTG analysis was determined with a Mettler Toledo TG/DTG 851e thermal analyzer from 25 °C to 800 °C with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. 4.2 Synthesis 4.2.1 2,5-bis(diphenylphosphanyl)pyrazine (L1) In N2 atmosphere, 2,5-dibromopyrazine (5 mmol, 1.2 g), NaOAc (11 mmol, 0.9 g), and Pd(OAc)2 (0.05 mmol, 12 mg) were added sequentially to 100 mL of dry DMF. Then, the obtained solution was added dropwise with diphenylphosphine (11 mmol, 1.9 mL) at room temperature (RT), and the resultant mixture was heated at 130 °C and stirred vigorously for 24 h. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was cooled to RT and then extracted with CH2Cl2/H2O. The organic phases were collected, dried over magnesium sulfate, and concentrated under vacuum. The crude product was purified with silica gel chromatography (light petroleum/ethyl acetate, 10/1, v/v) and recrystallized in n-hexane/CH2Cl2, giving a white solid as L1 (1.7 g, 76 % yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.39 (s, 2H), 7.46–7.37 (m, 20H). 31P NMR (203 MHz, CDCl3) δ −8.52. 4.2.2 2,3-bis(diphenylphosphanyl)pyrazine (L2) According the similar procedures as described for the synthesis of L1, L2 was prepared by replacing the starting material of 2,5-dibromopyrazine with 2,3-dibromopyrazine. L2 was obtained as a white solid in 82 % yield by silica gel chromatography (light petroleum/ethyl acetate, 10/1, v/v) and recrystallization in n-hexane/CH2Cl2. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.51 (s, 2H), 7.31–7.20 (m, 20H); 31P NMR (203 MHz, CDCl3) δ −11.28. 4.2.3 2,6-bis(diphenylphosphanyl)pyridine (L3) According the similar procedures as described for the synthesis of L1, L3 was prepared by replacing the starting material of 2,5-dibromopyrazine with 2,6-dichloropyridine. L3 was obtained as a white solid in 85 % yield by silica gel chromatography (light petroleum/CH2Cl2, 3/1, v/v) and recrystallization in n-hexane/CH2Cl2. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.40 (t, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H), 7.37–7.29 (m, 10H), 7.26 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 10H), 7.04 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H); 31P NMR (203 MHz, CDCl3) δ −3.90. 4.2.4 1,4-bis(diphenylphosphanyl)benzene (L4) According the similar procedures as described for the synthesis of L1, L4 was prepared by replacing the starting material 2,5-dibromopyrazine with 1,4-diiodobenzene. L4 was obtained as a white solid in 72 % yield by silica gel chromatography (light petroleum/ethyl acetate, 10/1, v/v) and recrystallization in n-hexane/CH2Cl2. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.38–7.30 (m, 20H), 7.30–7.21 (m, 4H); 31P NMR (203 MHz, CDCl3) δ −5.70. 4.3 Single-Crystal x-ray crystallography The intensity data for L1 was collected on a Bruker SMARTAPEX II diffractometer using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reduction included absorption corrections by the multiscan method. Structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least-squares using SHELXS-97 (Sheldrick, 1990), with all nonhydrogen atoms refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were added at their geometrically ideal positions and refined isotropically. The crystal data and refinement details were given in Table S3 . 4.4 General procedures for the cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of alkynes In a typical experiment, Pd(OAc)2 (11.3 mg, 0.05 mmol), L1 (44.8 mg, 0.1 mmol, or the other ligand) DTBPMB (19.8 mg, 0.05 mmol), and PTSA⋅H2O (95.1 mg, 0.5 mmol, or the other acid) were mixed with phenylacetylene (5.0 mmol, or the other alkyne) and methanol (3 mL, or the other alcohol). The mixture was added in a 50 mL sealed Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was pressured with CO. Then, the resultant mixture was stirred vigorously at the appointed conditions. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was cooled down to room temperature and slowly depressurized. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was diluted with dichloromethane for GC analysis to determine the conversion of phenylacetylene and yield of 1a (n-dodecane as the internal standard) and the product distribution (normalization method). And the products were further identified by GC-mass spectrometry. The obtained products were further identified by 1H/13C/19F NMR spectra (provided in SI). In the recycling experiments, upon the 1st-run reaction and the GC-analysis as described above, phenylacetylene (20 mmol) was added additionally to the reaction solution directly (without separation of the formed products), and then 3 MPa CO was charged to continue the reaction for next run. coredata.dc:description: The mono-metal relay catalysis is a good strategy for one-pot multi-step cascade process in which the specific catalysis can be switched upon the ligand exchange to match the requirements for each independent reaction but without mutual interference and quenching problem. Herein, the one-pot cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation of terminal alkynes was achieved by taking advantages of the mono-metallic (Pd) relay catalysis, wherein the two kinds of divergent di-phosphines of L1 and DTBPMB were involved. In this Pd(OAc)2-L1-DTBPMB system, due to the steric bulkiness of L1 and DTBPMB, the two type of catalysts including Pd(OAc)2-L1 and Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB co-existed independently and compatibly. Pd(OAc)2-L1 system was only in charge of the first-step carbonylation of alkynes towards the branched α,β-unsaturated esters with gem-positioned double bond. Subsequent, Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB system took over the carbonylation of the branched α,β-unsaturated esters to afford the target diesters. It was indicated Pd(OAc)2 -L1 system was an efficient and stable catalyst which could be recycled upon 15 runs for the first-step carbonylation. Anyway, Pd(OAc)2-DTBPMB system easily underwent deactivation, which degraded the recyclability of the Pd(OAc)2-L1-DTBPMB coupling system for this cascade bis-alkoxycarbonylation.
